mn35:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
mn35:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

mn35:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena saccako nigaṇṭhaputto vesāliyaṃ paṭivasati bhassappavādako paṇḍitavādo sādhusammato bahujanassa.
mn35:2.1.eng: Now at that time Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was staying in Vesālī. He was a controversialist who pretended to be astute and was deemed holy by many people.
mn35:2.1.comm: Saccaka is called nigaṇṭhaputta, being the only person so described. The nigaṇṭhas (“knotless ones”) were Jain ascetics and their followers were nigaṇṭhasāvaka (SN 42.9:2.3). The commentary says he was the son of Jain parents. From the ending of this sutta, where he makes an offering of food, we can see he was not an ascetic, and from MN 36:48.11 it is clear he was not a Jain. | This sutta includes a number of images, phrases, and allusions that appear reminiscent of the Brahmanical teacher Uddālaka Āruṇi, although none of the references are definitive. The bulk of Uddālaka’s teachings were to his son Śvetaketu, who became arrogant due to his learning (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.1.2), paralleling Saccaka’s arrogance.

mn35:2.2.pli: So vesāliyaṃ parisati evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
mn35:2.2.eng: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī,

mn35:2.3.pli: “nāhaṃ taṃ passāmi samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, saṅghiṃ gaṇiṃ gaṇācariyaṃ, api arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ paṭijānamānaṃ, yo mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddho na saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya, yassa na kacchehi sedā mucceyyuṃ.
mn35:2.3.eng: “I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits, were I to take them on in debate—not a leader of an order or a community, or the tutor of a community, and not even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn35:2.4.pli: Thūṇaṃ cepāhaṃ acetanaṃ vādena vādaṃ samārabheyyaṃ, sāpi mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddhā saṅkampeyya sampakampeyya sampavedheyya.
mn35:2.4.eng: Even an insentient post would shake and rock and tremble were I to take it on in debate.

mn35:2.5.eng: How much more then a human being!”

mn35:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā assaji pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn35:3.1.eng: Then Venerable Assaji robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
mn35:3.1.comm: Assaji was one the group of five mendicants who received the Buddha’s first discourse (Kd 1:6.36.1). Shortly afterwards he inspired Sāriputta with a classic epitome of the teaching (Kd 1:23.2.1). Note that Sāriputta waited politely until almsround was complete before approaching, whereas Saccaka just goes right ahead. We hear of a grave illness Assaji suffered later (SN 22.88). | Another Assaji, who is always paired with his friend Punabbasuka, was a lazy and indulgent monk (MN 70:4.1).

mn35:3.2.pli: Addasā kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto vesāliyaṃ jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn35:3.2.eng: As Saccaka was going for a walk he saw Assaji coming off in the distance.

mn35:3.3.pli: Disvāna yenāyasmā assaji tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā assajinā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn35:3.3.eng: He approached him and exchanged greetings with him.

mn35:3.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto āyasmantaṃ assajiṃ etadavoca:
mn35:3.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Saccaka stood to one side and said to Assaji,

mn35:4.1.pli: “kathaṃ pana, bho assaji, samaṇo gotamo sāvake vineti, kathaṃbhāgā ca pana samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattatī”ti?
mn35:4.1.eng: “Worthy Assaji, how does the ascetic Gotama guide his disciples? And on what topics does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”
mn35:4.1.comm: Sāvake vineti (“guide his disciples”) is typically used by non-Buddhists. | The phrase kathaṁbhāgā (and its counterpart evaṁbhāgā in the next line) are unique. The literal sense is “with what portion”, and given the answer I think Saccaka is asking for a list of topics.

mn35:4.2.pli: “Evaṃ kho, aggivessana, bhagavā sāvake vineti, evaṃbhāgā ca pana bhagavato sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattati:
mn35:4.2.eng: “Aggivessana, this is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and his instructions to disciples generally proceed on these topics:
mn35:4.2.comm: Saccaka is addressed with the Bramanical clan name Aggivessana, probably after the lineage of his clan’s purohita, just as the Sakyans are called Gotama and the Mallas Vāseṭṭha. A Vajjiputta is referred to as Gotama at Thag 1.119.

mn35:4.3.pli: ‘rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā, saññā aniccā, saṅkhārā aniccā, viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ.
mn35:4.3.eng: ‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.
mn35:4.3.comm: The five aggregates are mentioned as if the listener is expected to know them.

mn35:4.4.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṃ anattā.
mn35:4.4.eng: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.

mn35:4.5.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.
mn35:4.5.eng: All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’

mn35:4.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, aggivessana, bhagavā sāvake vineti, evaṃbhāgā ca pana bhagavato sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattatī”ti.
mn35:4.6.eng: This is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and how instruction to his disciples generally proceeds.”
mn35:4.6.comm: Despite this, this teaching that omits “suffering” (dukkha) is not taught by the Buddha at all. It only appears in one other sutta, where it is spoken by the mendicants after the Buddha’s passing (SN 22.90:2.2; but see below at MN 35:9.5). Strikingly, both the current sutta and SN 22.90 share a common narrative pattern. In both cases, an interlocuter (Saccaka or Channa, both known for their conceit) asks for teaching from a lesser teacher (Assaji or unnamed mendicants). Their reply omits suffering, but this fails. So they seek a better teacher (the Buddha, Ānanda) who not only includes suffering, but specially emphasizes it (MN 35:21.2, SN 22.90:9.7). This teaching is successful. This narrative journey mirrors that of Śvetaketu, who studied with others for twelve years before being shown true wisdom by his father Uddālaka. If we are on the right track, the point of the narrative is that it is essential to include suffering. This suggests that the Chinese parallels (SA 110 at T ii 35b4 and EA 37.10 at T ii 715b4), which do include the characteristic of dukkha here, would be a product of later expansion and normalization.

mn35:4.7.pli: “Dussutaṃ vata, bho assaji, assumha ye mayaṃ evaṃvādiṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ assumha.
mn35:4.7.eng: “It’s sad to hear, worthy Assaji, that the ascetic Gotama has such a doctrine.

mn35:4.8.pli: Appeva nāma mayaṃ kadāci karahaci tena bhotā gotamena saddhiṃ samāgaccheyyāma, appeva nāma siyā kocideva kathāsallāpo, appeva nāma tasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā viveceyyāmā”ti.
mn35:4.8.eng: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet the worthy Gotama, and we can have a discussion. And hopefully I can dissuade him from this harmful misconception.”

mn35:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcamattāni licchavisatāni santhāgāre sannipatitāni honti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
mn35:5.1.eng: Now at that time around five hundred Licchavis were sitting together at the town hall on some business.
mn35:5.1.comm: The Licchavis, whose name is derived from “bear”, dominated the Vajji Federation.

mn35:5.2.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto yena te licchavī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te licchavī etadavoca:
mn35:5.2.eng: Then Saccaka went up to them and said,

mn35:5.3.pli: “abhikkamantu bhonto licchavī, abhikkamantu bhonto licchavī, ajja me samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo bhavissati.
mn35:5.3.eng: “Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama.

mn35:5.4.pli: Sace me samaṇo gotamo tathā patiṭṭhissati yathā ca me ñātaññatarena sāvakena assajinā nāma bhikkhunā patiṭṭhitaṃ, seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso dīghalomikaṃ eḷakaṃ lomesu gahetvā ākaḍḍheyya parikaḍḍheyya samparikaḍḍheyya;
mn35:5.4.eng: If he stands by the position stated to me by one of his well-known disciples—a mendicant named Assaji—I’ll take him on in debate and drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong man would grab a fleecy sheep and drag it to and fro and round about!

mn35:5.5.pli: evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ ākaḍḍhissāmi parikaḍḍhissāmi samparikaḍḍhissāmi.

mn35:5.6.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma balavā soṇḍikākammakāro mahantaṃ soṇḍikākiḷañjaṃ gambhīre udakarahade pakkhipitvā kaṇṇe gahetvā ākaḍḍheyya parikaḍḍheyya samparikaḍḍheyya;
mn35:5.6.eng: Taking him on in debate, I’ll drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong brewer’s worker would toss a large brewer’s sieve into a deep lake, grab it by the corners, and drag it to and fro and round about!

mn35:5.7.pli: evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ ākaḍḍhissāmi parikaḍḍhissāmi samparikaḍḍhissāmi.

mn35:5.8.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma balavā soṇḍikādhutto vālaṃ kaṇṇe gahetvā odhuneyya niddhuneyya nipphoṭeyya;
mn35:5.8.eng: Taking him on in debate, I’ll shake him down and about, and give him a beating, like a strong brewer’s mixer would grab a strainer by the corners and shake it down and about, and give it a beating!

mn35:5.9.pli: evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ odhunissāmi niddhunissāmi nipphoṭessāmi.

mn35:5.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kuñjaro saṭṭhihāyano gambhīraṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā sāṇadhovikaṃ nāma kīḷitajātaṃ kīḷati;
mn35:5.10.eng: I’ll play a game of hemp-washing with the ascetic Gotama, like a sixty-year-old elephant would plunge into a deep lotus pond and play a game of hemp-washing!
mn35:5.10.comm: Hemp was beaten and washed in water before being woven into ropes or cloth.  (Also at MN 56:7.10; see AN 10.99:3.4 for an elephant’s “ear-washing”.)

mn35:5.11.pli: evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ sāṇadhovikaṃ maññe kīḷitajātaṃ kīḷissāmi.

mn35:5.12.pli: Abhikkamantu bhonto licchavī, abhikkamantu bhonto licchavī, ajja me samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo bhavissatī”ti.
mn35:5.12.eng: Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama.”

mn35:6.1.eng: At that, some of the Licchavis said,

mn35:6.2.pli: “kiṃ samaṇo gotamo saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa vādaṃ āropessati, atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropessatī”ti?
mn35:6.2.eng: “How can the ascetic Gotama refute Saccaka’s doctrine, when it is Saccaka who will refute Gotama’s doctrine?”

mn35:6.3.eng: But some of the Licchavis said,

mn35:6.4.pli: “kiṃ so bhavamāno saccako nigaṇṭhaputto yo bhagavato vādaṃ āropessati, atha kho bhagavā saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa vādaṃ āropessatī”ti?
mn35:6.4.eng: “Who is Saccaka to refute the Buddha’s doctrine, when it is the Buddha who will refute Saccaka’s doctrine?”

mn35:6.5.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto pañcamattehi licchavisatehi parivuto yena mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā tenupasaṅkami.
mn35:6.5.eng: Then Saccaka, escorted by the five hundred Licchavis, went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.

mn35:7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā bhikkhū abbhokāse caṅkamanti.
mn35:7.1.eng: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.

mn35:7.2.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
mn35:7.2.eng: Then Saccaka went up to them and said,

mn35:7.3.pli: “kahaṃ nu kho, bho, etarahi so bhavaṃ gotamo viharati?
mn35:7.3.eng: “Good fellows, where is the worthy Gotama at present?

mn35:7.4.pli: Dassanakāmā hi mayaṃ taṃ bhavantaṃ gotaman”ti.
mn35:7.4.eng: For we want to see him.”

mn35:7.5.pli: “Esa, aggivessana, bhagavā mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisinno”ti.
mn35:7.5.eng: “Aggivessana, the Buddha has plunged deep into the Great Wood and is sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.”

mn35:8.1.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto mahatiyā licchaviparisāya saddhiṃ mahāvanaṃ ajjhogāhetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn35:8.1.eng: Then Saccaka, together with a large group of Licchavis, went to see the Buddha in the Great Wood, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn35:8.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn35:8.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

mn35:8.3.pli: Tepi kho licchavī appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu, appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mn35:8.3.eng: Before sitting down to one side, some of the Licchavīs bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

mn35:9.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:9.1.eng: Then Saccaka said to the Buddha,

mn35:9.2.pli: “puccheyyāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ, sace me bhavaṃ gotamo okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
mn35:9.2.eng: “I’d like to ask the worthy Gotama about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

mn35:9.4.pli: “Kathaṃ pana bhavaṃ gotamo sāvake vineti, kathaṃbhāgā ca pana bhoto gotamassa sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattatī”ti?
mn35:9.4.eng: “How does the worthy Gotama guide his disciples? And on what topics does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”

mn35:9.5.pli: “Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, sāvake vinemi, evaṃbhāgā ca pana me sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattati:
mn35:9.5.eng: “This is how I guide my disciples, and my instructions to disciples generally proceed on these topics:
mn35:9.5.comm: If, as I have argued, Assaji’s presentation is meant to be inadequate, why does the Buddha endorse it here? The Buddha commonly endorses answers given by disciples, and this could have been a product of editorial standardization. After all, it remains the fact that it simply is not true that the Buddha normally teaches in this way.

mn35:9.6.pli: ‘rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā, saññā aniccā, saṅkhārā aniccā, viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ.
mn35:9.6.eng: ‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.

mn35:9.7.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṃ anattā.
mn35:9.7.eng: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.

mn35:9.8.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.
mn35:9.8.eng: All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’

mn35:9.9.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, sāvake vinemi, evaṃbhāgā ca pana me sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattatī”ti.
mn35:9.9.eng: This is how I guide my disciples, and how instruction to my disciples generally proceeds.”

mn35:10.2.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

mn35:10.3.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, ye kecime bījagāmabhūtagāmā vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti, sabbe te pathaviṃ nissāya pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya.
mn35:10.3.eng: “All the plants and seeds that achieve growth, increase, and maturity do so depending on the earth and grounded on the earth.
mn35:10.3.comm: Saccaka argues by naturalistic analogy from singularity to plurality. Likewise Uddālaka, observing the natural world, pointed to the way that multiplicity emerges from singleness. When asked who he worships as self, Uddālaka answers the “earth”, which is said to be the “ground” (pratiṣṭhā, Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.17); due to this worship he enjoys food and offspring. However, he points to water rather than earth as the origin of anna, which is (plant) food but also stands for solidity in general (6.2.4; see too 6.11.1–2).

mn35:10.4.pli: Evamete bījagāmabhūtagāmā vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti.

mn35:10.5.pli: Seyyathāpi vā pana, bho gotama, ye kecime balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyanti, sabbe te pathaviṃ nissāya pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya.
mn35:10.5.eng: All the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth.

mn35:10.7.pli: Evameva kho, bho gotama, rūpattāyaṃ purisapuggalo rūpe patiṭṭhāya puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā pasavati, vedanattāyaṃ purisapuggalo vedanāyaṃ patiṭṭhāya puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā pasavati, saññattāyaṃ purisapuggalo saññāyaṃ patiṭṭhāya puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā pasavati, saṅkhārattāyaṃ purisapuggalo saṅkhāresu patiṭṭhāya puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā pasavati, viññāṇattāyaṃ purisapuggalo viññāṇe patiṭṭhāya puññaṃ vā apuññaṃ vā pasavatī”ti.
mn35:10.7.eng: In the same way, an individual person’s self is form. Established on form they brim with merit and wickedness. An individual person’s self is feeling … perception … choices … consciousness. Established on consciousness they brim with merit and wickedness.”
mn35:10.7.comm: Saccaka treats the five aggregates as categories for classifying the self. And indeed elsewhere, such as DN 1, we find various theorists describe the self as “form”, experiencing “feelings”, being “percipient”, etc. In identifying each of the five aggregates as self, Saccaka follows the method of “affirmation” whereby multiple phenomena are affirmed to be the self at deeper and deeper levels, in contrast with the method of “negation” where potential candidates for the self are denied until the final self is revealed. Uddālaka also preferred the method of affirmation, arguing that existence comes first and that the divinity pours itself in all the manifold forms of the world (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.2.2 ff.). | Note Saccaka’s use of the term “individual person” (purisapuggala), for which see SN 22.22 and notes.

mn35:11.2.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā, vedanā me attā, saññā me attā, saṅkhārā me attā, viññāṇaṃ me attā’”ti?
mn35:11.2.eng: ‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’?”

mn35:11.3.eng: “Indeed, worthy Gotama, that is what I am saying.

mn35:11.4.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā, vedanā me attā, saññā me attā, saṅkhārā me attā, viññāṇaṃ me attā’ti, ayañca mahatī janatā”ti.
mn35:11.4.eng: And this big crowd agrees with me!”

mn35:11.5.eng: “What has this big crowd to do with you?

mn35:11.6.pli: Iṅgha tvaṃ, aggivessana, sakaññeva vādaṃ nibbeṭhehī”ti.
mn35:11.6.eng: Please just unpack your own statement.”

mn35:11.7.eng: “Then, worthy Gotama, what I am saying is this:

mn35:11.8.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā, vedanā me attā, saññā me attā, saṅkhārā me attā, viññāṇaṃ me attā’”ti.
mn35:11.8.eng: ‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’.”

mn35:12.1.pli: “Tena hi, aggivessana, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
mn35:12.1.eng: “Well then, Aggivessana, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

mn35:12.3.pli: vatteyya rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa sakasmiṃ vijite vaso—
mn35:12.3.eng: Consider an anointed aristocratic king such as Pasenadi of Kosala or Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha.

mn35:12.4.pli: ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetuṃ, jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetuṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetuṃ, seyyathāpi rañño pasenadissa kosalassa, seyyathāpi vā pana rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassā”ti?
mn35:12.4.eng: Would they have the power in their own realm to execute those who have incurred execution, fine those who have incurred fines, or banish those who have incurred banishment?”
mn35:12.4.comm: The Pali uses the future passive participle, sometimes interpreted as “deserving of execution”. But this would imply that the Buddha endorsed capital punishment, which is unsupported elsewhere and contradicts his ethical principles. Rather, read in its weaker literal sense, “execute those to be executed”, i.e. those who have been found guilty of a crime incurring capital punishment. It is an acknowledgment of the king’s powers, not an endorsement of them.

mn35:12.5.pli: “Vatteyya, bho gotama, rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa sakasmiṃ vijite vaso—
mn35:12.5.eng: “An anointed king would have such power, worthy Gotama.

mn35:12.6.pli: ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetuṃ, jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetuṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetuṃ, seyyathāpi rañño pasenadissa kosalassa, seyyathāpi vā pana rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa.

mn35:12.7.pli: Imesampi hi, bho gotama, saṅghānaṃ gaṇānaṃ—

mn35:12.9.eng: have such power in their own realm.
mn35:12.9.comm: Saccaka cannily appeals to the Licchavis by asserting their right to rule.

mn35:12.10.pli: ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetuṃ, jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetuṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetuṃ.

mn35:12.11.pli: Kiṃ pana rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa, seyyathāpi rañño pasenadissa kosalassa, seyyathāpi vā pana rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa?
mn35:12.11.eng: So of course an anointed king such as Pasenadi or Ajātasattu

mn35:12.12.eng: would wield such power, as is their right.”
mn35:12.12.comm: Overstepping the Buddha’s position, Saccaka’s endorsement of capital punishment shows how far he has drifted from the non-violent doctrine of his Jain parents.

mn35:13.3.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā’ti, vattati te tasmiṃ rūpe vaso—
mn35:13.3.eng: ‘Form is my self,’ do you have power over that form to say:

mn35:13.4.pli: evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī”ti?
mn35:13.4.eng: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that’?”
mn35:13.4.comm: Also at SN 22.59:2.3. This responds to the “inner controller” (antaryāmin) of Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.7. Uddālaka learned this from the centaur Kabandha in Madra (near modern Islamabad). He challenges Yājñavalkya, who explains it as the self who lives in the midst of all things, unknown but knowing, controlling all from within.

mn35:13.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mn35:13.5.eng: When he said this, Saccaka kept silent.

mn35:13.6.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:13.6.eng: The Buddha asked the question a second time,

mn35:13.7.pli: “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, aggivessana, yaṃ tvaṃ evaṃ vadesi:

mn35:13.8.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā’ti, vattati te tasmiṃ rūpe vaso—

mn35:13.9.pli: evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī”ti?

mn35:13.10.pli: Dutiyampi kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto tuṇhī ahosi.

mn35:13.11.pli: Atha kho bhagavā saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:13.11.eng: So the Buddha said to Saccaka,

mn35:13.12.pli: “byākarohi dāni, aggivessana, na dāni te tuṇhībhāvassa kālo.
mn35:13.12.eng: “Answer now, Aggivessana. Now is not the time for silence.

mn35:13.13.pli: Yo koci, aggivessana tathāgatena yāvatatiyaṃ sahadhammikaṃ pañhaṃ puṭṭho na byākaroti, etthevassa sattadhā muddhā phalatī”ti.
mn35:13.13.eng: If someone fails to answer a legitimate question when asked three times by the Buddha, their head explodes into seven pieces there and then.”
mn35:13.13.comm: The threat of losing one’s head is found at eg. Chāndogya Upaniṣad 1.8.6 and Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.24, or at 3.9.26 when it actually did fall off. I cannot trace the detail of heads being split in seven to any early Sanskrit texts, but it is found in later texts such as Rāmāyaṇa 7.26.44c and Mahābhārata 14.7.2c.

mn35:14.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena vajirapāṇi yakkho āyasaṃ vajiraṃ ādāya ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa uparivehāsaṃ ṭhito hoti:
mn35:14.1.eng: Now at that time the spirit Vajirapāṇī, taking up a burning iron thunderbolt, blazing and glowing, stood in the air above Saccaka, thinking,
mn35:14.1.comm: Vajirapāṇī (“lightning-bolt in hand”) appears here and in the parallel passage at DN 3:1.21.1. The synonymous Vajrahasta (Pali vajirahattha, DN 20:12.1) is a frequent epithet of Indra in the Vedas (eg. indro vajrahastaḥ, Rig Veda 1.173.10a), confirming the commentary’s identification with Sakka. Much later, Mahayana texts adopted the name for a fierce Bodhisattva who was protector of the Dhamma.

mn35:14.2.pli: “sacāyaṃ saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavatā yāvatatiyaṃ sahadhammikaṃ pañhaṃ puṭṭho na byākarissati etthevassa sattadhā muddhaṃ phālessāmī”ti.
mn35:14.2.eng: “If this Saccaka doesn’t answer when asked a third time, I’ll blow his head into seven pieces there and then!”

mn35:14.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana vajirapāṇiṃ yakkhaṃ bhagavā ceva passati saccako ca nigaṇṭhaputto.
mn35:14.3.eng: And both the Buddha and Saccaka could see Vajirapāṇī.

mn35:14.4.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto bhagavantaṃyeva tāṇaṃ gavesī bhagavantaṃyeva leṇaṃ gavesī bhagavantaṃyeva saraṇaṃ gavesī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:14.4.eng: Saccaka was terrified, shocked, and awestruck. Looking to the Buddha for shelter, protection, and refuge, he said,

mn35:14.5.eng: “Ask me, worthy Gotama. I will answer.”

mn35:15.3.pli: ‘rūpaṃ me attā’ti, vattati te tasmiṃ rūpe vaso—
mn35:15.3.eng: ‘Form is my self,’ do you have power over that form to say:

mn35:15.4.pli: evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī”ti?
mn35:15.4.eng: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that’?”

mn35:16.1.comm: Here neither “attention” nor “focus” quite fits manasikāra. The Buddha is telling Saccaka to recollect an earlier statement when making a later one, i.e. to practice rationality.

mn35:16.3.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn35:16.3.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn35:16.6.pli: ‘vedanā me attā’ti, vattati te tissaṃ vedanāyaṃ vaso—
mn35:16.6.eng: ‘Feeling is my self,’ do you have power over that feeling to say:

mn35:16.7.pli: evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī”ti?
mn35:16.7.eng: ‘May my feeling be like this! May it not be like that’?”

mn35:17.3.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn35:17.3.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn35:17.6.pli: ‘saññā me attā’ti, vattati te tissaṃ saññāyaṃ vaso—
mn35:17.6.eng: ‘Perception is my self,’ do you have power over that perception to say:

mn35:17.7.pli: evaṃ me saññā hotu, evaṃ me saññā mā ahosī”ti?
mn35:17.7.eng: ‘May my perception be like this! May it not be like that’?”

mn35:18.3.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn35:18.3.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn35:18.6.pli: ‘saṅkhārā me attā’ti, vattati te tesu saṅkhāresu vaso—
mn35:18.6.eng: ‘Choices are my self,’ do you have power over those choices to say:

mn35:18.7.pli: evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun”ti?
mn35:18.7.eng: ‘May my choices be like this! May they not be like that’?”

mn35:19.3.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn35:19.3.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn35:19.6.pli: ‘viññāṇaṃ me attā’ti, vattati te tasmiṃ viññāṇe vaso—
mn35:19.6.eng: ‘Consciousness is my self,’ do you have power over that consciousness to say:

mn35:19.7.pli: evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī”ti?
mn35:19.7.eng: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that’?”

mn35:20.3.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn35:20.3.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn35:20.7.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn35:20.7.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
mn35:20.7.comm: Here the Buddha introduces “suffering”, despite its omission earlier.

mn35:20.9.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn35:20.9.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn35:20.10.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
mn35:20.10.comm: This directly rejects all forms of self, but especially the highest conception of self as expressed in the Upaniṣads. Etaṁ mama occurs as mamedaṁ (“this is mine”, Maitrī Upaniṣad 3.2), which in context is a limited view of self. Eso’hamasmi is Yājñavalkya’s so’hamasmi (“I am that”, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.1; BU 5.15.1 = Īśā Upaniṣad 16; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.11.1, 4.12.1, 4.13.1; Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 3.6), which Uddālaka’s tattvamasi puts in second person (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.8.7). The same passage also parallels eso me attā with sa ātmā (“that is the self”), for which we also find eṣa ma ātmā (CU 3.14.3), and in the optative mood, ma idaṁ syād ātman (BU 1.2.7).

mn35:20.16.pli: taṃ kiṃ maññasi, aggivessana, viññāṇaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?

mn35:20.18.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn35:20.18.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn35:20.20.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn35:20.20.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn35:20.21.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn35:21.2.pli: yo nu kho dukkhaṃ allīno dukkhaṃ upagato dukkhaṃ ajjhosito, dukkhaṃ ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassati, api nu kho so sāmaṃ vā dukkhaṃ parijāneyya, dukkhaṃ vā parikkhepetvā vihareyyā”ti?
mn35:21.2.eng: Consider someone who resorts, draws near, and clings to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ Would they be able to completely understand suffering themselves, or live having wiped out suffering?”

mn35:21.6.pli: nanu tvaṃ evaṃ sante dukkhaṃ allīno dukkhaṃ upagato dukkhaṃ ajjhosito, dukkhaṃ:
mn35:21.6.eng: This being so, aren’t you someone who resorts, draws near, and clings to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn35:21.7.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’ti samanupassasī”ti?

mn35:22.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, puriso sāratthiko sāragavesī sārapariyesanaṃ caramāno tiṇhaṃ kuṭhāriṃ ādāya vanaṃ paviseyya.
mn35:22.1.eng: “Suppose, Aggivessana, there was a person in need of heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest.

mn35:22.2.pli: So tattha passeyya mahantaṃ kadalikkhandhaṃ ujuṃ navaṃ akukkukajātaṃ.
mn35:22.2.eng: There they’d see a big banana trunk, straight and young and grown unskewed.

mn35:22.3.pli: Tamenaṃ mūle chindeyya, mūle chetvā agge chindeyya, agge chetvā pattavaṭṭiṃ vinibbhujeyya.
mn35:22.3.eng: They’d cut it down at the base, cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths.

mn35:22.4.pli: So tattha pattavaṭṭiṃ vinibbhujanto pheggumpi nādhigaccheyya, kuto sāraṃ?
mn35:22.4.eng: But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.

mn35:22.5.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, aggivessana, mayā sakasmiṃ vāde samanuyuñjiyamāno samanugāhiyamāno samanubhāsiyamāno ritto tuccho aparaddho.
mn35:22.5.eng: In the same way, when pursued, pressed, and grilled by me on your own doctrine, you turn out to be vacuous, hollow, and mistaken.

mn35:22.6.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te esā, aggivessana, vesāliyaṃ parisati vācā:
mn35:22.6.eng: But it was you who stated before the assembly of Vesālī:

mn35:22.7.pli: ‘nāhaṃ taṃ passāmi samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā, saṅghiṃ gaṇiṃ gaṇācariyaṃ, api arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ paṭijānamānaṃ, yo mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddho na saṅkampeyya na sampakampeyya na sampavedheyya, yassa na kacchehi sedā mucceyyuṃ.
mn35:22.7.eng: ‘I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits, were I to take them on in debate—not a leader of an order or a community, or the tutor of a community, and not even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn35:22.8.pli: Thūṇaṃ cepāhaṃ acetanaṃ vādena vādaṃ samārabheyyaṃ sāpi mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddhā saṅkampeyya sampakampeyya sampavedheyya.
mn35:22.8.eng: Even an insentient post would shake and rock and tremble were I to take it on in debate.

mn35:22.9.eng: How much more then a human being!’

mn35:22.10.pli: Tuyhaṃ kho pana, aggivessana, appekaccāni sedaphusitāni nalāṭā muttāni, uttarāsaṅgaṃ vinibhinditvā bhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhitāni.
mn35:22.10.eng: But sweat is pouring from your forehead; it’s soaked through your robe and drips on the ground.
mn35:22.10.comm: The oddly prominent role of sweat in the discourse finds its parallel in Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.2.3, where Uddālaka argues that existence (sat) produces fire (tejas) and fire produces water, which is why you sweat when hot.

mn35:22.11.pli: Mayhaṃ kho pana, aggivessana, natthi etarahi kāyasmiṃ sedo”ti.
mn35:22.11.eng: While I now have no sweat on my body.”

mn35:22.12.pli: Iti bhagavā tasmiṃ parisati suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ kāyaṃ vivari.
mn35:22.12.eng: So the Buddha revealed his golden body to the assembly.

mn35:22.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
mn35:22.13.eng: When this was said, Saccaka sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

mn35:23.1.pli: Atha kho dummukho licchaviputto saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ maṅkubhūtaṃ pattakkhandhaṃ adhomukhaṃ pajjhāyantaṃ appaṭibhānaṃ viditvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:23.1.eng: Knowing this, the Licchavi Dummukha said to the Buddha,
mn35:23.1.comm: Dummukha the Licchavi appears only here. The name, meaning “Ugly Face” seems odd, but it is also a term for a horse. A number of individuals of this name appear in Sanskritic literature, including one from Uddālaka’s home country of Pañcāla (Aitareya Brāhmaṇa 8.23).

mn35:23.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

mn35:23.4.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhante, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre pokkharaṇī.
mn35:23.4.eng: “Sir, suppose there was a lotus pond not far from a town or village,
mn35:23.4.comm: The same simile appears at SN 4.24:8.1.

mn35:23.6.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā kumārakā vā kumārikā vā tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā nikkhamitvā yena sā pokkharaṇī tenupasaṅkameyyuṃ; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā taṃ kakkaṭakaṃ udakā uddharitvā thale patiṭṭhāpeyyuṃ.
mn35:23.6.eng: Then several boys or girls would leave the town or village and go to the pond, where they’d pull out the crab and put it on solid ground.

mn35:23.7.pli: Yaññadeva hi so, bhante, kakkaṭako aḷaṃ abhininnāmeyya taṃ tadeva te kumārakā vā kumārikā vā kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sañchindeyyuṃ sambhañjeyyuṃ sampalibhañjeyyuṃ.
mn35:23.7.eng: Whenever that crab extended a claw, those boys or girls would snap, crack, and break it off with a stick or a stone.
mn35:23.7.comm: The crab “extends” a claw as a meditator after absorption “extends” the mind to insight (MN 4:27.1). See too the simile at SN 35.240.

mn35:23.8.pli: Evañhi so, bhante, kakkaṭako sabbehi aḷehi sañchinnehi sambhaggehi sampalibhaggehi abhabbo taṃ pokkharaṇiṃ puna otarituṃ, seyyathāpi pubbe.
mn35:23.8.eng: And when that crab’s claws had all been snapped, cracked, and broken off it wouldn’t be able to return down into that lotus pond.

mn35:23.9.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, yāni saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa visūkāyitāni visevitāni vipphanditāni tānipi sabbāni bhagavatā sañchinnāni sambhaggāni sampalibhaggāni;
mn35:23.9.eng: In the same way, sir, the Buddha has snapped, cracked, and broken off all Saccaka’s twists, ducks, and dodges.

mn35:23.10.pli: abhabbo ca dāni, bhante, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto puna bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamituṃ yadidaṃ vādādhippāyo”ti.
mn35:23.10.eng: Now he can’t get near the Buddha again looking for a debate.”

mn35:24.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto dummukhaṃ licchaviputtaṃ etadavoca:

mn35:24.2.pli: “āgamehi tvaṃ, dummukha, āgamehi tvaṃ, dummukha, (…) na mayaṃ tayā saddhiṃ mantema, idha mayaṃ bhotā gotamena saddhiṃ mantema.
mn35:24.2.eng: “Hold on, Dummukha, hold on! I wasn’t talking with you, I was talking with the worthy Gotama.

mn35:24.3.pli: Tiṭṭhatesā, bho gotama, amhākañceva aññesañca puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ vācā.
mn35:24.3.eng: Worthy Gotama, leave aside that statement I made—as did various other ascetics and brahmins—

mn35:24.4.eng: it was, like, just a bit of nonsense.
mn35:24.4.comm: Saccaka tries to wriggle out of his initial statement, just as modern trolls claim to speak in irony or humor.

mn35:24.5.pli: Kittāvatā ca nu kho bhoto gotamassa sāvako sāsanakaro hoti ovādapatikaro tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane viharatī”ti?
mn35:24.5.eng: How do you define a disciple of the worthy Gotama who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions?”

mn35:24.6.pli: “Idha, aggivessana, mama sāvako yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati;
mn35:24.6.eng: “It’s when one of my disciples truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
mn35:24.6.comm: This is the trainee (sekha). Knowing Saccaka’s attachment to his self theories, the Buddha frames his response with the standard passage on not-self.

mn35:24.7.eng: They truly see any kind of feeling …

mn35:24.10.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
mn35:24.10.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn35:24.11.pli: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, mama sāvako sāsanakaro hoti ovādapatikaro tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane viharatī”ti.
mn35:24.11.eng: That’s how to define one of my disciples who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.”

mn35:25.1.pli: “Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto”ti?
mn35:25.1.eng: “But how do you define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment?”

mn35:25.2.pli: “Idha, aggivessana, bhikkhu yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti;
mn35:25.2.eng: “It’s when a mendicant truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping.

mn35:25.3.eng: They truly see any kind of feeling …

mn35:25.6.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
mn35:25.6.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping.

mn35:25.7.pli: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṃyojano sammadaññāvimutto.
mn35:25.7.eng: That’s how to define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.

mn35:26.1.pli: Evaṃ vimuttacitto kho, aggivessana, bhikkhu tīhi anuttariyehi samannāgato hoti—
mn35:26.1.eng: A mendicant whose mind is freed like this has three unsurpassable qualities:

mn35:26.2.comm: Also at DN 33:1.10.119, which is doubtless lifted from the current passage. A list of six unsurpassables is found at AN 6.30, but the only common item is “seeing” (dassana), which is defined as seeing the Buddha and his disciples. Here “seeing” is either seeing the Buddha which gives rise to faith, or else “seeing” the four noble truths; practice is the noble eightfold path; and freedom is the result of that path, arahantship. | As to why this unique set is chosen here, it is perhaps notable that three of the final similes of Uddālaka’s “subtlest” self (as above, MN 35:20.10) in the Chāndogya Upaniṣad speak of seeing (the kernel of a seed, 6.12.1–2), walking (from one village to the next, 6.14.2), and freedom (from punishment, 6.16.2).

mn35:26.3.pli: Evaṃ vimuttacitto kho, aggivessana, bhikkhu tathāgataññeva sakkaroti garuṃ karoti māneti pūjeti—
mn35:26.3.eng: They honor, respect, esteem, and venerate only the Realized One:

mn35:26.4.pli: buddho so bhagavā bodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, danto so bhagavā damathāya dhammaṃ deseti, santo so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṃ deseti, tiṇṇo so bhagavā taraṇāya dhammaṃ deseti, parinibbuto so bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammaṃ desetī”ti.
mn35:26.4.eng: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and quenched. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, self-control, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment.’”

mn35:27.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:27.1.eng: When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him,

mn35:27.2.pli: “mayameva, bho gotama, dhaṃsī, mayaṃ pagabbā, ye mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ āsādetabbaṃ amaññimha.
mn35:27.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, it was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate.

mn35:27.3.pli: Siyā hi, bho gotama, hatthiṃ pabhinnaṃ āsajja purisassa sotthibhāvo, na tveva bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ āsajja siyā purisassa sotthibhāvo.
mn35:27.3.eng: For a person might find safety after attacking a rutting elephant, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.

mn35:27.4.pli: Siyā hi, bho gotama, pajjalitaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ āsajja purisassa sotthibhāvo, na tveva bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ āsajja siyā purisassa sotthibhāvo.
mn35:27.4.eng: A person might find safety after attacking a blazing mass of fire, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.

mn35:27.5.pli: Siyā hi, bho gotama, āsīvisaṃ ghoravisaṃ āsajja purisassa sotthibhāvo, na tveva bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ āsajja siyā purisassa sotthibhāvo.
mn35:27.5.eng: They might find safety after attacking a poisonous viper, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.

mn35:27.6.pli: Mayameva, bho gotama, dhaṃsī, mayaṃ pagabbā, ye mayaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ āsādetabbaṃ amaññimha.
mn35:27.6.eng: It was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate.

mn35:27.7.pli: Adhivāsetu me bhavaṃ gotamo svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
mn35:27.7.eng: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”

mn35:28.1.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā te licchavī āmantesi:
mn35:28.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Saccaka addressed those Licchavis,

mn35:28.2.pli: “suṇantu me bhonto licchavī, samaṇo me gotamo nimantito svātanāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
mn35:28.2.eng: “Listen, gentlemen. I have invited the ascetic Gotama together with the Saṅgha of mendicants for tomorrow’s meal.

mn35:28.3.pli: Tena me abhihareyyātha yamassa patirūpaṃ maññeyyāthā”ti.
mn35:28.3.eng: You may all bring me what you think is suitable.”

mn35:29.1.pli: Atha kho te licchavī tassā rattiyā accayena saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa pañcamattāni thālipākasatāni bhattābhihāraṃ abhihariṃsu.
mn35:29.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, those Licchavis presented Saccaka with an offering of five hundred servings of food.
mn35:29.1.comm: The idiom “presented with servings of food” (thālipākaā bhattābhihāraṁ) is elevated, occurring only in the context of aristocracy and sacrifice.

mn35:29.2.pli: Atha kho nigaṇṭhaputto sake ārāme paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
mn35:29.2.eng: And Saccaka had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own park. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,

mn35:29.3.eng: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”

mn35:30.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena saccakassa nigaṇṭhaputtassa ārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
mn35:30.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Saccaka’s park, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn35:30.2.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mn35:30.2.eng: Then Saccaka served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

mn35:30.3.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn35:30.3.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Saccaka took a low seat and sat to one side.

mn35:30.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn35:30.4.eng: Then Saccaka said to the Buddha,

mn35:30.5.pli: “yamidaṃ, bho gotama, dāne puññañca puññamahī ca taṃ dāyakānaṃ sukhāya hotū”ti.
mn35:30.5.eng: “Worthy Gotama, may the merit and the growth of merit in this gift be for the happiness of the donors.”
mn35:30.5.comm: Puññamahī (“flourishing of merit”), for which there are several variants in text and commentary, is found only here and at AN 7.53:6.10, where it also concerns the dedication of merit to another. It might refer to the glorious results of merit, for which compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.2, “endowed with that (divine fruit for which he wished) he flourishes (tena sampanno mahīyate). Or else it might invoke the idea that merit flourishes depending on the recipient (MN 142), like a seed on the earth (mahī; cp. puññakkhetta), which fits nicely with the Buddha’s response here. | Bhikkhu Bodhi’s remark that Saccaka “must have still considered himself a saint” is unwarranted, as the same phrase at AN 7.53 is used by a devoted lay follower. Clearly he was arrogant, but it was others who called him sādhu.

mn35:30.6.pli: “Yaṃ kho, aggivessana, tādisaṃ dakkhiṇeyyaṃ āgamma avītarāgaṃ avītadosaṃ avītamohaṃ, taṃ dāyakānaṃ bhavissati.
mn35:30.6.eng: “Aggivessana, whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as yourself—who is not free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to the donors.
mn35:30.6.comm: According to one of the Chinese parallels, this statement was made by the Buddha in answer to a question by the mendicants after returning to the monastery (SA 110 at T ii 37b22).

mn35:30.7.pli: Yaṃ kho, aggivessana, mādisaṃ dakkhiṇeyyaṃ āgamma vītarāgaṃ vītadosaṃ vītamohaṃ, taṃ tuyhaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
mn35:30.7.eng: Whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as myself—who is free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to you.”
